greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Primorial primes: primes of the form 1 + product of first k primes, for some k.
comment: Prime numbers that are the sum of two primorial numbers. - _Juri-Stepan Gerasimov_, Nov 08 2010
reference: F. Iacobescu, Smarandache Partition Type and Other Sequences, Bull. Pure Appl. Sciences, Vol. 16E, No. 2 (1997), pp. 237-240.
link: M. Fleuren, Factors and primes of Smarandache sequences.

R. Mestrovic, Euclid's theorem on the infinitude of primes: a historical survey of its proofs (300 BC--2012) and another new proof, arXiv preprint arXiv:1202.3670, 2012 - From N. J. A. Sloane, Jun 13 2012
F. Smarandache, Sequences of Numbers Involved in Unsolved Problems.
formula: a(n) = 1 + A002110(A014545(n)), where A002110(k) is the product of the first k primes. - _M. F. Hasler_, Jun 23 2019
example: a(1) = 2 = 1 + product of the first 0 primes (i.e., the empty product = 1).
a(2) = 3 = 1 + 2 = 1 + product of the first prime (= 2).
a(3) = 7 = 1 + 2*3 = 1 + product of the first two primes.
a(4) = 31 = 1 + 2*3*5 = 1 + product of the first three primes.
a(5) = 211 = 1 + 2*3*5*7 = 1 + product of the first four primes.
a(6) = 2311 = 1 + 2*3*5*7*11 = 1 + product of the first five primes.
Then the product of the first 6, 7, ..., 9 or 10 primes does not yield a primorial prime, the next one is:
and so on. See A014545 = (0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 11, 75, 171, 172, ...) for the k's that yield a term. (End)
mathematica: Select[FoldList[Times, 1, Prime[Range[200]]] + 1, PrimeQ]. (* Loreno Heer (helohe(AT)bluewin.ch), Jun 29 2004 *)
program: (PARI) P=1;print1(2); forprime(p=2,1e6, if(isprime(1+P*=p), print1(", "P+1))) \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Apr 28 2015
xref: A005234 and A014545 (which are the main entries for this sequence) give more terms.
results.author: _Murray R. Bremner_
